messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Sim-MEES: Modular End-Effector System Grasping Dataset for Mobile Manipulators in Cluttered Environments

Paper Abstract: Abstract In this paper, we present Sim-MEES: a large-scale synthetic dataset that contains 1,550 objects with varying difficulty levels and physics properties, as well as 11 million grasp labels for mobile manipulators to plan grasps using different gripper modalities in cluttered environments. Our dataset generation process combines analytic models and dynamic simulations of the entire cluttered environment to provide accurate grasp labels. We provide a detailed study of our proposed labeling process for both parallel jaw grippers and suction cup grippers, comparing them with state-of-the-art methods to demonstrate how Sim-MEES can provide precise grasp labels in cluttered environments.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Grasp planning in complex scenes",
        "A mobile manipulation system for one-shot teaching of complex tasks in homes",
        "Tiago - mobile manipulator robot",
        "Modular end-effector system for autonomous robotic maintenance & repair",
        "Neural Network-Based Pose Estimation Approaches for Mobile Manipulation",
        "Fetch mobile manipulator",
        "2f-85 and 2f-140 grippers.",
        "Shapenet: An information-rich 3d model repository",
        "Benchmarking in manipulation research: The YCB object and model set and benchmarking protocols",
        "Omniverse platform for virtual collaboration.",
        "Dex-net 1.0: A cloud-based network of 3d objects for robust grasp planning using a multi-armed bandit model with correlated rewards",
        "Robotic grasping of novel objects using vision",
        "Using experience for assessing grasp reliability.",
        "Learning visual similarity for product design with convolutional neural networks",
        "Real-time grasp detection using convolutional neural networks",
        "Data-driven grasp synthesisâ€”a survey",
        "Grasp pose detection in point clouds",
        "Generating robust grasps for unknown objects in clutter using point cloud data",
        "Gpr: Grasp pose refinement network for cluttered scenes",
        "Real-time grasp pose estimation for novel objects in densely cluttered environment",
        "Graspness discovery in clutters for fast and accurate grasp detection",
        "Vgpn: 6-dof grasp pose detection network based on hough voting",
        "Robotic grasp detection based on image processing and random forest",
        "High precision grasp pose detection in dense clutter",
        "Template-based learning of grasp selection",
        "Robotic pick-and-place of novel objects in clutter with multi-affordance grasping and cross-domain image matching",
        "Graspnet-1billion: A large-scale benchmark for general object grasping",
        "Learning hand-eye coordination for robotic grasping with large-scale data collection",
        "Learning suction graspability considering grasp quality and robot reachability for bin-picking",
        "A billion ways to grasp: An evaluation of grasp sampling schemes on a dense, physics-based grasp data set",
        "Pointnetgpd: Detecting grasp configurations from point sets",
        "Dex-net 3.0: Computing robust vacuum suction grasp targets in point clouds using a new analytic model and deep learning",
        "Object-agnostic suction grasp affordance detection in dense cluster using self-supervised learning.docx",
        "End-to-end learning to grasp from object point clouds",
        "Learning ambidextrous robot grasping policies",
        "Suctionnet-1billion: A large-scale benchmark for suction grasping",
        "Efficient grasping from rgbd images: Learning using a new rectangle representation",
        "Jacquard: A large scale dataset for robotic grasp detection",
        "Acronym: A large-scale grasp dataset based on simulation",
        "6-dof graspnet: Variational grasp generation for object manipulation",
        "The new wave in robot grasping",
        "Gpu-accelerated robotic simulation for distributed reinforcement learning",
        "Real-Time Rendering 4th Edition",
        "Openpcdet: An open-source toolbox for 3d object detection from point clouds",
        "Rmpflow: A computational graph for automatic motion policy generation",
        "A cnn-based grasp planning method for random picking of unknown objects with a vacuum gripper"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Sim-MEES: Modular End-Effector System Grasping Dataset for Mobile Manipulators in Cluttered Environments, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
